content.title: Acrocyanosis
content.definition: Persistent, painless, symmetric blue discoloration of the hands and feet due to vasospasm of small cutaneous arterioles with secondary dilation of capillaries and venules. A benign functional vascular disorder exacerbated by cold exposure.

key_concepts.description: Primary (idiopathic, benign) vs Secondary (associated with underlying diseases: anorexia nervosa, connective tissue disorders, malignancy, infections)
Arteriolar vasoconstriction with compensatory capillary and venular dilation; increased oxygen extraction causes desaturated hemoglobin accumulation causing blue color; no true tissue ischemia
Persistent symmetric blue discoloration of hands/feet; cool, moist skin; worsened by cold, improved by warmth; painless (key distinguishing feature); no ulceration or gangrene
Unlike Raynaud: acrocyanosis is continuous (not episodic), symmetric, painless, and lacks the triphasic color change (white→blue→red); no clear demarcation between affected and normal tissue
Anorexia nervosa (very common association); connective tissue disorders; malignancy; infections; drug-induced (ergotamine, β-blockers); cold agglutinin disease; hematologic disorders
Blue hands and feet without sharp demarcation; cool and moist; normal pulses; hyperhidrosis; no trophic changes, ulcers, or gangrene
Primarily clinical diagnosis; rule out secondary causes (CBC, ANA, cryoglobulins, cold agglutinins); pulse oximetry and ABI normal; no imaging typically needed
Reassurance for primary form (benign); cold avoidance; warm gloves and socks; treat underlying cause for secondary form; vasodilators rarely needed and limited efficacy
Primary acrocyanosis is benign with no long-term complications; does not progress to tissue loss; cosmetic concern primarily; secondary forms depend on underlying disease

learning_objectives: Define acrocyanosis and distinguish from Raynaud phenomenon
Recognize the benign nature of primary acrocyanosis
Identify secondary causes, especially anorexia nervosa
Understand that it is painless and does not cause tissue loss
clinical_pearls: Persistent blue hands/feet + painless + symmetric = acrocyanosis
Raynaud: episodic, triphasic, painful; Acrocyanosis: continuous, painless
Very common in anorexia nervosa - always consider eating disorder
Benign - no ulcers, no gangrene, no progression
Reassurance is the main treatment for primary form
common_mistakes: Ordering extensive vascular workup for benign primary acrocyanosis
